moves.3. Nc3: 3. Nf3 is usually played first, to stop the Slav Gambit, 3......e7-e5, but in fact it has never been played against me, and the game transposes.
moves.4. Nf3: White too follows the main line.
moves.4... e6: The Semi-Slav, which can be reached by other move orders.
moves.5. Bg5: I play the common pin variation. 5....Nb-d7 is playable now followed by 6.....Qa5 - the Cambridge Springs variation.
moves.5... dxc4: This pawn capture is common in the Slav.
moves.6. e4: Played after a long think.6. a4 is also playable.
moves.6... b5: He hangs on to the pawn on c4.
moves.7... h6: Forced, otherwise he loses knight for pawn.
moves.9. Nxg5: This is a temporary sacrifice of a knight.
moves.10... Nbd7: He does this so that he can recapture on f6.
moves.11... Qb6: I found out afterwards that actually Bb7 instead of Qb6 is good for black. This is good for white now.
moves.13. Qxf6: I take back, hitting the rook.
moves.13... Rg8: The natural square for the rook.
moves.14. O-O-O: Protecting my d pawn with my rook, and moving the king out of the center. I found out later that this position has been seen in this game. http://gameknot.com/analyze-board.pl?bd=14169707&mv=27&rnd=0.03949373448267579
moves.14... Be7: White has no choice now, as Qh6?? and Qf4?? both lose the queen to Bg5.
moves.16. Ne4: In the aforementioned game white continued Qe2? instead of Ne4 with advantage to black. Ne4 is played to discourage c6-c5. In computer analysis afterwards, we found that black can still play c6-c5! and meet dxc5 with Qxc5! and if white takes the black queen, black can take the white queen. That is probably the best continuation for black.
moves.17. Qe3: Again, played to prevent the freeing c6-c5.
moves.17... Qa5: Black hits the pawn on a2.
moves.18. a3: If instead I had played Kb1, then black has got c6-c5, as my d pawn can't take on c5 as he can play Rd8xRd1+. So this is the only way to protect it. I was planning on meeting b5-b4 with Nc5.
moves.18... Rd7: He starts wasting time, leading to a massive advantage for me. b5-b4 was better.
moves.19. Rg1: So I finally prepare to develop my king side.
moves.19... Kd8: He decides to remove his king from the center.
moves.21... Rdd8: He retreats, black is entirely passive now.
moves.24. g5: I want to play Qg3, but not allowing him to play a bishop or even a rook to h4
moves.28. Qc3: With thoughts of switching to the queen side. Also an immediate h5-h6 drops the pawn to Rxh6 and I can't recapture without losing my queen, if it is still on g3.
moves.28... Qd8: So his queen comes back to prevent my queen from invading.
moves.30. a4: With thoughts of opening up the queen side.
moves.34... Kc7: He protects again. This is where I missed a quicker win. 35.	a5 Qxa5 36. Qxc6+  wins for example Kb8 37. Qa8+ Kc7 38.Qa7+ Kd8 39. d5. The higher boards in my team all saw this - which perhaps shows why they have a slight edge over me!
moves.37. Kc2: With dreams of opening up the queen-side, by putting my rooks on a1 and b1 and playing b2-b3, but it is not the best move.
moves.37... Qa5: Ok, stop and find white's next move!
moves.38. Bxf7: Did you find it? I should have played it a move earlier, when it was even stronger.
moves.39. g6: Now these pawns can't be stopped.
moves.39... Rf5: Rook moves out of the way.
moves.41. g8=Q: Good enough, but h6-h7 was even stronger, and would have caused my opponent to resign, he confided to me later.
moves.44. Kd2: I want to find safety on the king-side.
moves.45. Qd4: He can't take it, as I have a mating attack, starting with Qd8+.
moves.47... Rxh6: This is an error, but black is hopelessly lose anyway.
moves.49. Qd6+: And my opponent realizes that he is about to get mated and resigns. Many thanks for reading. Please leave a comment or two and rate the annotation on the "star" system.
